summary.long: Philemon is a book of the New Testament.

verses.text:
From: Paul, a prisoner of the Messiah Jesus, and Timothy our brother.
To: Philemon our dear friend and fellow worker,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to Apphia our sister, to Archippus our fellow soldier, and to the church in your house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May grace and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus, the Messiah, be yours!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I always thank my God when I mention you in my prayers,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because I keep hearing about your love for all the saints and the faith that you have in the Lord Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I pray that your partnership in the faith may become effective as you fully acknowledge every blessing that is ours in the Messiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have received considerable joy and encouragement from your love, because the hearts of the saints have been refreshed, brother, through you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this reason, although in the Messiah I have complete freedom to order you to do what is proper,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I prefer to make my appeal on the basis of love. I, Paul, as an old man and now a prisoner of the Messiah Jesus,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: appeal to you on behalf of my child Onesimus, whose father I have become during my imprisonment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once he was useless to you, but now he is very useful both to you and to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As I send him back, it’s like I’m coming along with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I wanted to keep him with me so that he could serve me in your place during my imprisonment for the gospel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet I did not want to do anything without your consent, so that your good deed might not be something forced, but voluntary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Perhaps this is why he was separated from you for a while, so that you could have him back forever,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: no longer as a slave but better than a slave—as a dear brother, especially to me, but even more so to you, both as a person and as a believer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So if you consider me a partner, welcome him as you would welcome me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he has wronged you in any way or owes you anything, charge it to my account.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, Paul, am writing this with my own hand: I will repay it. (I will not mention to you that you owe me your very life.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, brother, I desire this favor from you in the Lord. Refresh my heart in the Messiah!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Confident of your obedience, I am writing to you because I know that you will do even more than I ask.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, prepare a guest room for me, too, for I am hoping through your prayers to be returned to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Epaphras, my fellow prisoner in the Messiah Jesus, sends you greetings,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as do Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my fellow workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the grace of our Lord Jesus, the Messiah, be with your spirit! Amen.
verses.speaker: Narrator
